title: Fibroblast Mediated Vasculogenesis and Blood-Thymic Barrier System of Fish
content: Anabas testudineus (Bloch, 1792) is a freshwater teleost (climbing perch), belonging to the Order: Perciformes, Family: Anabantidae of South East Asia, ‘Least Concern’ in Red Data book (IUCN, Ver. 3.1). In fish, the thymus gland is a primary lymphoid organ: ‘Old Gland’ [1], always exposed to the external aquatic environment. The thymus gland is not well demarcated by the cortex and medulla, but this glandular structure is a site of cellular integration, viz., lymphoid and non-lymphoid cellular components [2]. The thymic vascular net-working system and the rejuvenation of thymic trabeculae are the regular events of cellular homeostasis [3]. Interestingly, the periodic occurrence and frequency of fibroblast cells, morph of macrophages, mast cells, rodlet cells, cystic elements, etc. may show their definite identity within the thymic structure in different environmental conditions. Now, we focus on: how the degrees of blood vascular net-working system are consolidating the glandular protection through the influence of thymic stromal componential interactions in fish?
